reviewText:
Plantera is a casual clicker game that was released in January 2016, being developed by VargatP. You build your own garden and watch it grow before your own eyes.

Gameplay is really simplistic; you grow plants and reap the rewards by selling the crops. You get a bit more money, so you grow another plant, so on and so forth. You collect your crops by clicking on them, hence why this game is classified as a clicker.  The gameplay may sound quite boring to most, but it is strangely addictive. Not only do you have the option to grow plenty of plants, but you can also raise life stock to grant you additional funds as well. This life stock will also attract predators to your garden; you can either deal with the wolves and such on your own by clicking on them to make them run away, or hire guard dogs to do the deed for you.  As you grow more and more in your garden, you will eventually run out of space; meaning you need to expand your garden.  Your garden doesn’t stop growing and making you money when you quite the game though – you have helpers that will gather your harvest for you, meaning the majority of your money will come through downtime. Personally, I load up this game on a daily basis, to collect my gold, build a few new plants and then log out again.

Do not let my play time deceive you; I have been playing this game every day since it was released in January, but only for five minutes a day. That is all you need to get your fix and to continue growing your garden.

Graphically, Planter has a cute look to it, with some childlike character models in the farm animals and predators that break into your garden. The animations are simple but so beautifully done as well. This game is so colourful. The sound track is also one of the most gleaming features of this game; it’s so beautifully crafted and horribly catchy that you’ll be whistling the tune all day.

There is no difficulty to this game, you cannot fail and there is no real win state either. The aim is to simply grow your garden at a pace which suites you.  The majority of the achievements don’t really require any skill; you will unlock them with time and patience.

Plantera is a simple, yet brilliant game. It holds a special place in my daily Steam routines of loading it up and harvesting my crops, along with a handful of other clicker games such as Adventure Capitalist.  It is so perfectly priced too at a measly £1,99. You have nothing to lose by picking this game up!

reviewText:
Published by: VaragtP
Developed by: VaragtP
Genre: Casual, Indie, Simulation, Family-friendly
Release Date: 29 Jan, 2016

Create, expand and watch your garden grown in this super addictive and totally adorable casual clicker game.

IntroductionPlantera is a simple and highly addictive clicker game, where the basic objective is to build and expand your own garden. As your garden grows, you collect more coins which allow you to further boost your garden (and coin collecting efficiency). Boosters can be bought with the coins, which allow higher value of produce, collecting coins when the game isn’t running for larger periods (I can currently leave my game for 12 hours, and come back to a large sum of coins waiting for me!), and guard dogs and scarecrows to scare away the critters trying to steal your produce! Though I’m not generally a fan of clicker games, I have really enjoyed Plantera thus far.

GameplayThe general idea surrounding Plantera is that you build a garden, collecting coins in order to buy more land, more plants, animals and boosters whilst warding off the critters trying to steal your produce. As you collect more coins you are able to expand the land, thus expanding your garden size and capacity. As you expand land size, you obtain more helpers; round little blue creatures whose job it is to harvest plants and collect said coins.
Plants, bushes, trees and animals can all be placed in the garden to earn coins, and you can also manually click on butterflies and moles to gain even more (the helpers cannot collect these).
Leveling up will unlock different varieties of plants, bushes, trees and animals to add to your garden, and with every purchase of these, the price of each rises.

ControlsThe controls are very simplistic. As it is a clicker game, you basically do just that; click. The only time you will need your keyboard is when your garden has expanded in size enough that you need to navigate from one side to the other.

SoundtrackWhilst the upbeat soundtrack fits in very well with the game, it is very repetitive (it’s just the one song played over) which can get a little dull after a while.

GraphicsI absolutely adore the graphics. The colours used and the cute little cartoon creatures all tie in perfectly with the game’s theme.

Replay ValueThough I’m not sure if there is a maximum level (I’m currently level 67), I do believe the repetitive nature of the game may leave little replay value when a certain level is reached.

DifficultyThere is no real difficulty in Plantera; it would be appropriate for all age levels and skill levels respectively. The whole expanding process is fairly linear, thus leaving little room for fail; ie, you will essentially just keep earning coins and progressing no matter how you play it.

Overall VerdictA reasonable amount of interaction is needed when you first play Plantera, as you start with a blank garden and very few coins. Once you are able to build it up to a reasonably large size, you will be able to let it idle and check on your progress from time to time, which I think is a definite advantage for the casual player. How involved you wish to get is completely up to you; either click away and earn the coins yourself, or leave it up to your helpers, checking in from time to time to keep the progress going. There are limited variations as to what can be bought currently (4 each of plants, bushes, trees and animals), but that doesn’t affect the gameplay for me personally. The devs are continuing to add to the game which is fantastic.

Overall Score: 8/10

Plantera is a super cute gardening/clicker game. The game features cute music, cute animals and basically a well fun clicking game which can sort of get addicting.

Graphics:

The game features sort of 8-bit type graphics with bright colorful art-style. No big problem with FPS and it was generally running at 60 FPS for me all the time. The game is not that heavy on the graphics so you can play it on even old pc’s or pc’s without the latest graphics cards.

Sound:

The game has a cute theme track though it can get pretty old. So some variety would be nice but it was happy cheerful music which goes well with the game theme of happy animal/gardening type game.

Gameplay:

If like me you’re a fan of Clicker games, this game is very fun.  You start off with nothing on the screen except 3 butterflies which you (kill? I really hope our blue creature doesn’t kill those butterflies), so you get 1 coin from each butterfly. Once you have the 3 coins required to purchase your first plant you can start the game. You buy the carrots plants and your farming (no pun intended) begins. So basically you earn coins and build trees and plants and animals using coins.

Once the plants and trees are built the vegetables/fruits start to grow, animals start doing their thing which is laying eggs etc. When the fruits and vegetables grow full, you can go ahead and click them to either pull them from the ground if they’re a ground plant type or tear them away from the tree. A second click on the fruits/vegetable/animal products will collect them and give you coins. You gain levels by earning more and more coins and new plants/trees/animals get unlocked as you progress to new levels. All sorts of animals and plants and trees are available. E.g. apples, pears, carrots, pumpkins, turnips, chicken etc.

Every time you buy something their price goes up just like usual clicker games. There will be cute rabbits, birds and foxes trying to steal your fruits which you can prevent by clicking on them. Every once in a while a gopher will appear from the ground and you can click on it to earn a bit of extra coins, same with lady bugs which give you a lot of coins. There’ also a knight cameo and he runs across the screen and you can click on him multiple times to earn coins. The game also farms offline so if you quit the game and log back in later you’ll have a bunch of coins. The game will automatically save frequently so you won’t lose your progress.

There are upgrades available such as a scarecrow and guard dog which will help you get decrease the fruits/vegetable stolen by foxes, birds etc. Another upgrade is the alarm clock which will make your blue creature work faster. Another upgrade available is the multiplier which will increase your coins earned to double the amount and lasts forever, so this upgrade should be bought whenever you can. You can also purchase additional land and extend your garden. Though it’ll keep increasing in price every time you extend. A short gameplay video can be found below.

reviewText:
Plantera is a nice (and cute) twist on the standard clicker game that eventually (after two hours) just falls flat due to the lack of 'content'.

The idea of the game is really rather unique and the execution is solid. The music is pleasant (up to a certain point) and the graphics while being simple have a certain charm to them. The premise of the game is simply to build a garden/farm and harvest the crops. To do that you get little blue helper blobs that automate the process and have to fend off meanies that want to steal your crops. Otherwise it's the same 'click on something to get money' routine.

By gaining more money you level up and get access to more plants (and some animals). You also have to extend your garden to have more space to grow more plants. Alternatively you can also spend money on some extras like scarecrows, guard dogs or a permanent gold multiplicator. One rather 'unfortunate' update that you can buy that way is the time that your blue helper blobs will work while being offline. It's a bit like the game knows that it doesn't offer much and artificially makes you come back to it more frequently until you threw enough money at an otherwise completely pointless update...

The real problem of the game is the lack of variety. There are three categories of plants with five plants in them each and four animals that you can get. You unlock the lot within the first hour of play and afterwards you just deal with more of the same. There's one (overused) 'easter egg/cameo' special event, but there are no other specials to see or look forward to. The game play is bland even for a clicker. There no strategy or tactic at all. It's just waiting to get enough money to buy more things to get more money.

It's a nice idea, but it's worth a dollar at best. You'll get an hour or two of fun out of the game until it becomes utterly repetitive.

P.S.: I'm grinding for the last achievements that's why I have way more than two hours playtime, but I don't recommend doing the same.

In-depth Review about game mechanics and clicker genre- https://youtu.be/fjYbJBdUjoA

Plantera is a clicker game minus the clicking. It has all the traits of a clicker but the advantages of clicking are very minor, it’s more of a sit it and forget it kind of game. This time around the goal is to make as much money as possible, this allows you to increase the size of your plot, get more and better fauna and flora and defend yourself from the pesky critters.

Plantera is definitely more on the simpler size, and that’s saying a lot for a clicker game. While I have over 13hours played for the game I’d say only about an hour or so of that is actual gameplay. The reason for this is that while you gain full money while the game is not running, you can only gain a maximum of 1 level while the game is closed. Levels are extremely important as they are the main tool for progression, they unlock more farmers and increased fauna and flora quality and variety ,so they’re pretty much mandatory.

reviewText:
TL:DR at the end, scored 5 / 10 as of 18th April 2016
Borba likes:Genre - A clicker game, sporting full autonomy for idling, only requiring the player to purchase and place upgrades. Players may still speed up progress by picking up fruits and animal produce, or scaring off critters.

Interface - The interface is simple and functional, and was updated with button shortcuts to go to either extremity of the farm or to the center. The upgrades menu is toggle-able so we can appreciate all that goes in the background without having half the screen serving as a menu.

Graphics - Cute, appealing and colourful. Borba would love to see some more detail, such as day and night cycle or weather, but as is it’s pleasant to the eyes.

Design - Plantera feels unique from the get-go, and the few features it brings to the table are good in this genre. While it may lack mechanics and content to make it feel more rewarding and to prolong its lifetime, it’s a solid clicker game on it’s own, great for all ages.

Polish - No minor or major bugs were found, and no performance issues whatsoever. The game is still getting short updates so there’s hopes they might improve on some of its negative aspects.
Borba dislikes:Replayability - There is little reason to play after unlocking the achievements and steam cards, since there seem to be no mechanics to reset the game while carrying over bonuses to a new start. The current content can be unlocked in a couple of days, although the achievements may take a bit more than that.

Narrative - There’s no such thing in Plantera, yet Borba believes clicker games shouldn’t be an exception here, as it could add more value to the game itself.

Gameplay - As previously stated, players may purchase upgrades and items for their farms, despite being very limited in terms of variety. Fruits, vegetables and animal produce may be gathered by the player via clicking, or by automated workers that increase as the player expands the farm. Critters that may steal produce may also be clicked to scare away, although dogs and scarecrows may be purchased to help with that. Both active and passive progress don’t feel that much rewarding after a while, due to lack of content and features.

Music - The background tune is pleasant at first, but since there are no volume controls it will quickly become tiring and repetitive. Gladly, there is an option to mute. Volume controls and some variety in this field are a necessity.

Sound - The nature of the game makes it so that some of the sounds become too repetitive eventually and, if there was volume slider for sounds, this could be mitigated by having the sound low so players could still have audible feedback for their actions without being overwhelmed by the same loud sounds. Also, there are ambient noises that Borba only noticed when he muted the music, which would add a nice touch if everything else wasn’t so loud!
Borba feels like as an idle clicker game, Plantera provides all the basics required for a successful game of this genre. It’s ideal to keep open on the background or second screen while multi-tasking, despite lacking a bit in terms of depth and content while compared with certain more complex idle games. Due to its price, Borba believes it to be a good pick exclusively for fans of this type of games.

5 / 10

There are also specials you can buy like guard dogs to chase away critters, a clock that lets you earn money for a set time while being offline (although it's more profitable to leave the game running) and a multiplier which increases the worth of everything. Later on you can also expand your property so you can plant more things. It's very simple and there's not much to it yet I found it addictive. I hope the dev has plans to add more in the future.\n\nThere's no microtransaction system in place which I find surprising for this type of game. For a casual time waster I'd recommend it for the $3 price tag. Even better if ya can get it on sale.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Full Disclosure: I recieved review code for this game.

Plantera... Such a small and simple game, and yet so deep in its details that I'm almost afraid I might miss something. Imagine if you will, Farmville squashed flat vertically, with all the artwork changed and rodents in the veggies. Then change the art to super-kawaii, and you get something that resembles Plantera.

It's a casual game with an eye towards making things as easy to operate but difficult to keep up with if you're going for the quick high-score. It's a frantic clicker game that starts out small and simple, teaching you the basic moves, and then begging you to get ahead of yourself. Not for the Carpal Tunnel crowd, but certainly worth a look if you have a few minutes to kill while you're waiting for your bus or as the not-driver on a cross-country road trip. It's cheap and easy, like most of the other games of its type, but don't let the kyute fool you.

This game is all about your mad clicking skillz, and if you don't have it, you'd better learn quick. The assets are numerous and varied, to the degree that nearly everything I saw is easily identified at a glance rather than a guess. The music is in dire need of an actual volume control, but it does at least have an off switch so you can use the rest of the sound design to tell you what's going on.

65/100-- not for everybody, but it's an inexpensive and amusing way to assassinate the clock when needed. Should be a mobile port, and is not. I expect they're going to port it to mobile eventually.

It would do better on a tablet. Windowed mode looks like it set up for cell phones, and requires considerable precision to get anywhere. Fullscreen looks good, though. Your mileage may vary, of course.

TotalBiscuit says that a game is only a game if it contains a failure state.

Plantera is a game where you have to click things to gain money. Using this money, you can buy other things, that help you generate money faster, so you can buy more stuff that lets you generate more money, that lets you buy more things, ad infinitum, a la Cookie Clicker.

This game is indesputably more fun that Cookie Clicker - there's a lot going on, it's cute, there's actual graphics, as opposed to just clicking aimlessly, but it has pretty much the game gameplay. Or lack thereof. Just click things until you get bored, and then tab out and do something else, and tab back in when you want to play again.

Not paying attention to the game doesn't mean that you're losing anything. Profits may go down, but you aren't missing out. This isn't a game you need to pay attention to to play. Idle clicker is pretty much the perfect thing you could call this game.

It's got cute graphics, and it's got nice sound, but that's about all I like for this game. That's not necessarily a bad thing, but it's just not my thing. For what it is, the price is fair. But unless the graphics are your thing, just hang out with Cookie Cliker.

reviewText:
I've played a few clicker/idle type games, and this one unfortunately is lacking quite a bit. As other reviews have noted, the game is not free, whereas the majority of my experience has been with free games.

That being said, there are a few I'm actively playing, with elements that keep me interested. Namely, Clicker Heroes and AdVenture Capitalist. Both have events which keep up the variety, and both have long term, difficult to reach (without a lot of play time) goals. This keeps me engaged and coming back for more.

On the other hand, Plantera has very low replayability. The review panel here is telling me I've clocked just under 50 hours. That is 100% actual game time, as I did not leave the game closed for any extended period. Sure, you can do that, and get your earnings when you come back, but there are achievements that can only be obtained while having an active window open. -- And that's part of the problem. With my ~50 hours of play time, I picked up every single achievement. That might be good if you are a completionist, but it was far too easy. There were no goals that I could see taking more than a month to complete (versus the previously mentioned titles, which have achievements that take a very long time to get to), and because of that, there's not much you're going to get for your money here.

Also, in the 'late game' (which is really no different than earlier stages), the building upgrades are all passive, based on your level. So on top of the fact that the game doesn't change much over time, thus making it boring, there is nearly zero strategy to employ with regard to upgrade paths. There are some strategic elements, like how many dogs/scarecrows to use, but I found these had very minimal impact, especially if you were actively clicking all the time.

Now, that's not to say the game is all that bad. The animations are nice/cute, the expandable garden is a nice twist on the genre, and this game rewards active participation more than others. However, for the lack of content/total active play time provided, I would much rather have kept my money, considering the free alternatives available.

reviewText:
While Plantera is a cute game, I think it lacks in a lot of places.

I completed it in 21 hours, and 7 of those hours were while I was sleeping. It feels very, very short for an incremental game and the amount of content is pretty much abysmal. You get 5 plants, 5 bushes, 5 trees and 4 animals. That's it. You buy more land and plant more.

The critters that try to steal your fruits/vegetables have basically no impact. I get maybe 2-3 critters per 30 seconds on a farm that produces way too much for it to matter at all, the few fruits they manage to steal when my dogs don't do their job do not reduce my profits in any way.

The automation (Star) tab doesn't do much, in my opinion. I completed the game with a 10x multiplier, 10 scarecrows and 8 dogs. There is an upgrade to increase the amount of time your workers harvest while you close the game, but it's nearly useless considering how little time it takes to complete the game.

I don't think it's a bad game at all, and I think it does have potential. But the way it is right now, it's way too easy to finish it. It's not much fun in its current state, you just plant your things and leave the game running in the background. There's no point in clicking fruits or vegetables yourself, it honestly doesn't make much of a difference besides making the game even shorter.

reviewText:
Idle games occupy an interesting position in the video game climate. Most of us don’t really think of games like AdVenture Capitalist or Cookie Clicker as core video games, or even really recognize them as games at all. They’re really just distractions, nice ways to pass the time and still feel like you’re accomplishing something thanks to ever-increasing numbers, enticing you to get the higher amount of points your heart desires while waiting for your download to finish or microwave to beep. Little distractions, usually cute, and always a good way to fight off the always approaching threat of boredom. The issue is when an idle game manages to screw up even those basic fundamentals and becomes a bore itself.

Plantera has a charming aesthetic that makes for a nice screensaver and nothing much beyond that.

reviewText:
Name: Plantera
Developer: VaragtP
Release Date: 28th January 2016

Simple and addictive click based game
Plantera is a very simple and addictive click based game, where the basic objective is
to construct and enlarge your own garden. As your garden grows, you collect more coins
which allow you to further improve your garden. Boosters can be bought with the coins,
which allow higher value of produce, the ability to collect coins when the game
isn’t running for long periods of time and dogs/scarecrows to scare away the
critters trying to steal your produce! Though I’m not usually a fan of clicker games
i thoroughly enjoyed this one.

Gameplay:
Gameplay in Plantera is relatively simple in that you build a garden, collecting coins in
in order to buy more land, plants, animals and boosters whilst warding off
critters who are trying to steal your produce. As more coins are collected you are
able to expand the land, thus expanding your garden size and capacity. As you expand
garden size, you obtain more helpers; round little blue creatures whose job it is to
harvest plants and gather coins.

Features:
Controls are very simple as the main premice is just clicking, the only other buttons used are the arrow keys to scroll across your garden.
The graphics are great. The colours used and the nice little cartoon creatures all fit in perfectly with the games theme and while the games upbeat soundtrack fits it very well, it can be extremely repetitive (it’s just the one song played over and over) and can be a little annoying after a while.

reviewText:
It's actually pretty fun. It's a clicker game where you slowly make a garden and fuit and vegetables grow. You can click on the ripe produce to collect the money, or you can let your little blue helpers pick it up for you.

There are critters that will steal your produce, and you can buy upgrades like dogs that will chase away the critters, scarecrows to... scare crows away, etc.

As the game progresses, you'll unlock new bush and plot types, allowing you to grow produce that makes you more money per item, as well as expand your farm and increase the amount of blue helpers you have.

There isn't a huge amount of strategy in the game, so far as I've seen in my short playtime, but it's a satisfying experience, all the same.

It's an ideal game for people who like clickers, and or enjoy games where you can do some work on your farm, then let things play out for a while.

Plantera is wonderful. It's simplistic. It's an idle-game; you don't need to babysit the screen. You can click, but the benefits to doing so after the first few minutes are fairly minor, and at no point does the game try to forcefully keep your attention, or make you feel guilty about being inefficient, or forgetting you've left it open in the background. There's no need for complex spreadsheets, to minmax your way to lording your superior progression over the casuals. Absolutely worth the price.

reviewText:
So I got sent this out of the blue, for review purposes.  But first small background; I am very impatient when it comes to games, especially retail I feel like hiding features behind a time wall is padding and a type that should really only be used in free to play games or games that actually have a reason beyond 'its just how it works' like plot or some crap, such as a prolog.

Clicker games aren't something I enjoy really, with few exception (Parodies and the like)

But I do enjoy (mostly) games like Harvest Moon, and Animal crossing where there's farming and more to do.

This takes farming and is the most basic of clicking games, with a graphic style that looks like it was made without much thought, and bores me to death.  The leveling system is poorly thought out giving you only one new item per level with few exception, also I'd rather a proper tutorial than be given a item from a catagory each level, in addition to level you need to use money to buy a item and every time you buy a item the price doubles all the way up to 99 million (I think)
Which needless to say doesn't make sense in a farming game, a genre in which the standard is fixed pricing.  I'd really rather have fixed pricing that you work your way up to rather than waiting for levels to get the item which I could afford to buy a year ago.

Seriously feels like a free to play flash game would have more content than this, even for a price of three dollars off sale I'd avoid it.  If you're looking for a paid for farming game that's not only cute but is in a promising state for the future, I've heard things about Slime Rancher (Though I don't own it myself)  There also seems to be a good lineup for early 2016 as far as big budgets go, and hopefully a couple indie suprises so especially at this time it'd probably be best to save money.

reviewText:
So just to be clear, I was offered a steam key to look at/review this game, but this review is a completely unbiased opinion.

The truth of the matter is, I went into this game honestly not believing this was something that would be for me, but I like to keep an open mind.  But even if a game is specifically not catered for me personally, I believe myself to have an open enough mind that I can see whether a game is good or bad based on its own merit and the market it is trying to appeal to.

The gameplay was surprisingly addictive, once I got the farm really beginning to take shape, leveling up and getting access to new items to plant/use.  I liked that there would be different creatures that would attempt to thwart my plans of growing a great farm.  Admittedly, when I first started the game, I thought again that I wouldn't like it and would be done with it right away.  And then an hour passed, and I still wanted to play.  And then two hours passed, and I was still playing.  It's incredibly addictive and easy to play.

I enjoyed the music of the game as well.  Light in tone, it kept the right mood as you clicked continuously to earn that gold.  Granted, I believe it was just one song on a loop, but that's perfectly fine.  And who knows, perhaps there will be an update with more music added, as I see there are updates being added from time to time, including one recently.  But even if not, I believe it more than satisfies the mood within the game.

Are there features I would like to see added?  Well, I didn't get crazy far into the game, but I would love to see perhaps a day/night cycle.  Perhaps some various weather patterns?  Maybe these things are in the game already, so I apologize if I didn't get far enough to witness them, but if I were to ponder on features I would love in this game, I think that would give it an added variability that might be interesting for the player.

This game is something that surprisingly gave me a good period of enjoyment, and at the end of the day, that's what games are all about.  Entertainment and an escape from the real world.  It accomplished its goal, and I think a lot of people could enjoy this game if/when they give it a chance.  My biggest suggestion is play it for an hour or so and then make a decision.  The beginning game starts off slow, but then things begin to pick right up.

reviewText: The best way to describe this game is a side-scrolling, simplified, idle/clicker version of harvest moon. You choose what to plant and your helpers will harvest for you or you can actively click to harvest for yourself. The money earned from harvest can be used to expand the garden, increase the value of your harvests and increase the time your helpers will harvest after you close the game. There are also various garden invaders that will try to steal your harvest, but you can hire guard dogs and place scarecrows to scare them off. The more of something you have the more expensive it is to purchase the next of that item which promotes diversity in what you put in your garden. You also gain experience from harvesting to level up and unlock more things to buy or increase the value of harvests along with getting more helpers to harvest for you.\n\nI loved playing harvest moon and always wanted to play it on PC, this definitely scratched the same itch and is a very zen experience as you tend your garden. There is a slight learning curve with having to use the trash can and click on the little plant sign and then click the other trash can in the top left corner to remove plants, but once you figure it out it's pretty easy to manage your garden. Once planted things won't die and the harvests will never rot so the only way to lose anything is from the invaders which can be defended against using guard dogs and scarecrows. I have really enjoyed this game so far and it looks like I have plenty of game left to play, at this price point you definitely get your money's worth.

reviewText:
Clear cut clicker" game mixed with a Farmville theme. As expected you start the early game massively spamming your mouse button trying to collect carrots. After upgrading from carrots and gaining more "helpers" (the blue guys that are sorta aimless and don't help TOO much) you begin to realise that you don't end up clicking less but only clicking more. As the trees/bushes both drop fruit it will be stacked quite high on the ground while playing since your helpers are slow at collecting the fruit.

Graphically this game is a sprite based 2D game as most clickers but it has a nice charm to it. The characters are quite cute and the sprites are clear to tell apart with colours being very vibrant. The music and sound effects though leave much to be desired. The same short music loop plays endlessly for the entire game so you will be muting that quite quickly and when collecting fruits and other things they make the same "clink" coin sound every time. This means by mid-game you will be hearing that more than 10-times per second.

Like other clicker games (Sakura Clicker among others) while you're not in the game your workers will still collect coins. This is good but this system is usually easily exploited by changing the computers clock time (may not work on this game). Otherwise this game is a very app-like game with mass clicking which is no suprise since the developers last game was a mobile game.

I'd say for $2.99 this game does not have DLC or any Microtransactions so you can get a full clicker experience here with a new theme and cute art design. If you enjoy clickers than this game will feed your strange addiction 7/10."
